claim: Israel's official X account made a post on Feb. 4, 2024, about humanitarian aid it said it had provided to Gaza that included a video clip showing an unrelated Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova.
content:
The protracted, often bloody Israeli-Palestinian conflict exploded into a hot war on Oct. 7, 2023, when the militant Palestinian group Hamas launched a deadly attack on Israel and Israel retaliated by bombarding the Gaza Strip. More than 20,000 people, the vast majority of them Palestinians, were reportedly killed during the first two months of the war alone. The violence is driven by mutual hostilities and territorial ambitions dating back more than a century. The internet has become an unofficial front in that war and is rife with misinformation, which Snopes is dedicated to countering with facts and context. You can help. Read the latest fact checks. Submit questionable claims. Become a Snopes Member to support our work. We welcome your participation and feedback.
On Feb. 4, 2024, the @Israel account on X — Israel's official presence on the social media platform — posted a 30-second video listing the humanitarian aid it claimed it had provided for the people of Gaza in the months since the Israel-Hamas war began.
A claim emerged the following week that footage included in the video depicted an unrelated Ukrainian refugee camp, not Gaza. We rate this claim as "True."
Above the video in the post on X, the caption included a list that claimed Israel had provided aid to Gazans in the form of 11,000 trucks, 140,000 tons of food, 1,000 water trucks, 17,000 tons of medical supplies and 23,000 tons of tents and shelter equipment.
"Israel will continue to facilitate the transfer of life-saving humanitarian aid to Gaza," the post continued. "Our war is with Hamas, not with the people of Gaza." The post ended with the hashtag #FreeGazaFromHamas.
During the brief video, a narrator's voice-over mentioned the same statistics regarding aid Israel said it had provided to Gaza.
"Israel does not limit the amount of humanitarian aid that can enter Gaza," the narrator began. "Since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, over 11,000 trucks of humanitarian aid have entered Gaza, carrying over 140,000 tons of food, over 1,000 water trucks, almost 17,000 tons of medical supplies and approximately 23,000 tons of tents and shelter equipment. We are at war with Hamas, not the people of Gaza."
Eight days later, on Feb. 12, @Israel's post and video from @Israel were no longer available and appeared to have been deleted. Shortly before the post disappeared, BBC Verify journalist Shayan Sardarizadeh reported via X, "The official state of Israel account has posted this video, saying it is facilitating aid into Gaza. A short clip at the end of the video, claiming to show tents and shelter equipment for Gazans, was actually filmed in March 2022, showing tents in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees."
The official state of Israel account has posted this video, saying it is facilitating aid into Gaza.
A short clip at the end of the video, claiming to show tents and shelter equipment for Gazans, was actually filmed in March 2022, showing tents in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees. pic.twitter.com/gKW2O1VdPF
— Shayan Sardarizadeh (@Shayan86) February 12, 2024

The same brief video clip that appeared at the end of the video posted by @Israel to represent "approximately 23,000 tons of tents and shelter equipment" was available on the Getty Images website, where it was dated as having been recorded on March 21, 2022. It was originally described as follows: "Land arranged on the territory of Moldova with tents near the border of Ukraine for refugees coming from the war in Ukraine."
This video clip had nothing to do with Israel or Gaza.
As of this writing, the same video that had been posted and removed from the @Israel account on X was available from official social media accounts for the Embassy of Israel in the U.S., including on Facebook, X, Instagram and TikTok.
Snopes reached out to Israel's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to ask about the removed post and will update this story if a response is received.

original_rationales.main_rationale: A short clip at the end of the video, claiming to show tents and shelter equipment for Gazans, was actually filmed in March 2022, showing tents in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees.
original_rationales.addtional_rational2: This video clip had nothing to do with Israel or Gaza.

summary_rationales.synthesized_rationale: The 'True' rating is justified based on substantial evidence that the video included in Israel's post about humanitarian aid to Gaza actually showed a Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova, not Gaza. This discrepancy between the claimed and actual content of the video supports the 'True' rating.

detailed_reasons.reason1: The information revealed by a BBC Verify journalist showing that the footage at the end of Israel's aid video was from a different location and time, namely a Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova, establishes a clear mismatch between the video's depiction and the claimed context of aid to Gaza.
detailed_reasons.reason2: The availability of the same video clip on Getty Images, with a description indicating its origin as a site near the border of Ukraine for Ukrainian refugees, further corroborates the inconsistency in the video presented by Israel as aid provided to Gaza.
detailed_reasons.reason3: The deletion of the post from Israel's official social media accounts after it was pointed out that the footage was from Moldova, not Gaza, confirms the misrepresentation of the content and strengthens the argument for the 'True' rating.
detailed_reasons.reason4: The statement made by the narrator in the video mentioning the aid provided to Gaza directly contradicts the reality of the footage being unrelated to Gaza, highlighting a significant discrepancy between the narrative and the visual evidence.

evidence1: The protracted, often bloody Israeli-Palestinian conflict exploded into a hot war on Oct. 7, 2023, when the militant Palestinian group Hamas launched a deadly attack on Israel and Israel retaliated by bombarding the Gaza Strip. More than 20,000 people, the vast majority of them Palestinians, were reportedly killed during the first two months of the war alone. The violence is driven by mutual hostilities and territorial ambitions dating back more than a century. relationship_with_evidence.<main_rationale,evidence1>: Refute. The evidence contradicts the rationale detail by describing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the involvement of Hamas and Israel in a war, while the rationale detail focuses on the misinformation related to humanitarian aid provided by Israel.

relationship_with_evidence.<addtional_rational2,evidence1>: Refute. The evidence directly contradicts the rationale detail as it talks about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and violence in Gaza, while the rationale mentions a video clip about humanitarian aid in Gaza that actually showed a Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason1,evidence1>: Refute. The evidence provided focuses on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the violence between the two parties, which is not directly related to the specific issue of misrepresentation in the video regarding the aid to Gaza. Therefore, the evidence contradicts the rationale's claim of a mismatch in the video's depiction and the context of aid to Gaza.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason2,evidence1>: Refute. The evidence provided discusses the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the violence in the region, which is not directly related to the content of the rationale detailing the inconsistency in the video clip presented by Israel as aid to Gaza. Therefore, the evidence contradicts the rationale.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason3,evidence1>: Supportive. The evidence directly supports the rationale detail by confirming that Israel's official social media post was indeed deleted after the misrepresentation of content was pointed out, thus strengthening the argument for the 'True' rating.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason4,evidence1>: Refute. The evidence provided discusses the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the humanitarian situation in Gaza, which is directly contradictory to the rationale detailing how the video footage shown in the post about humanitarian aid to Gaza was actually from a Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova, highlighting a significant discrepancy between the narrative and the visual evidence.

relationship_with_evidence.<main_rationale,evidence2>: Refute. The evidence directly contradicts the rationale detail by showing that the video claiming to be related to Gazans was actually filmed in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees.

relationship_with_evidence.<addtional_rational2,evidence2>: Refute. The evidence clearly contradicts the rationale detail as it states that the video clip showing tents and shelter equipment for Gazans in Gaza was actually filmed in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees, indicating a direct opposition to the claim that the video had nothing to do with Israel or Gaza.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason1,evidence2>: Refute. The evidence directly contradicts the rationale by revealing that the footage in Israel's aid video, which claimed to be of Gaza, was actually from a Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova. This establishes a clear mismatch between the depicted content and the claimed context of aid to Gaza.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason2,evidence2>: Refute. The evidence directly contradicts the rationale by showing that the video presented by Israel as aid provided to Gaza was actually filmed in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees, which opposed the claimed content and origin of the video.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason3,evidence2>: Refute. The evidence directly contradicts the rationale detail by confirming that the footage shown in the post was actually from Moldova, not Gaza, which strengthens the argument for the 'True' rating.

relationship_with_evidence.<reason4,evidence2>: Refute. The evidence contradicts the rationale detail as the video clip mentioned aid provided to Gaza, but actually showed footage of tents and shelter equipment for Ukrainian refugees in Moldova. This direct contradiction highlights a significant discrepancy between what was stated and what was visually represented.
